name: TheAtlantic
text: Once a COVID-19 vaccine is approved, federal and state governments still have to distribute it. And a whole new round of trouble could start, reports @sarahzhang: https://t.co/W9IuPWnrSf

name: TheAtlantic
text: "When you look at how many people vote in general elections, it's just not enough. There's no way that government can work properly if it can't accurately reflect who we are as a nation." The actor @ChrisEvans on the inspiration for @ASP: https://t.co/LYfiZbmYqK #TheAtlanticFest https://t.co/iw0hrTelrk

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Two proposals are gaining momentum among commentators and progressive activists: expanding the number of justices and instituting term limits. These ideas almost always seem to smack of political revenge," Lawrence Goldstone writes: https://t.co/7yh6aIdzMx

name: TheAtlantic
text: Sign up for the newsletter here: https://t.co/xf4jj5UekE

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: “The conservative Christian elites Trump surrounds himself with have always been more clear-eyed about his lack of religiosity than they’ve publicly let on.” https://t.co/e0bjKupcFh

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @beccarosen: Absolutely beautiful little set of essays by @AdamHSays on the children who desegregated America's schools, and the adults they are today https://t.co/oA6lDwAJBG

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @mckaycoppins: Former aides say they’ve heard Trump privately ridicule conservative religious leaders, dismiss faith groups with cartoonish stereotypes, and deride rites and doctrines held sacred by many in his base.

My story on what Trump really thinks about religion: https://t.co/T8UyQ5bprr

name: TheAtlantic
text: 1/6 The Supreme Court decided that segregation of public schools was unconstitutional—but it was thousands of children who actually desegregated America’s classrooms, writes @beccarosen. Here are five of their stories. Introducing #TheFirsts: https://t.co/neW0LiwCeD

name: TheAtlantic
text: 2/6 Hugh Price and his family fought for him to be one of the first Black students at an all-white high school in Washington, D.C. Once he was there, he “couldn’t wait for it to be over,” @adamhsays reports. https://t.co/XKdEcpPLcx

name: TheAtlantic
text: 3/6 Jo Ann Allen Boyce and 11 other students desegregated their high school in Clinton, Tennessee. Then the riots came, @adamhsays writes. https://t.co/uFv4tDT74A

name: TheAtlantic
text: 4/6 Sonnie Hereford IV desegregated Alabama’s public schools in 1963. He was only 6 years old. By @adamhsays: https://t.co/EKloAGmika

name: TheAtlantic
text: 5/6 Millicent Brown changed Charleston, then watched it stay the same, @adamhsays reports. https://t.co/bAbqSqc08t

name: TheAtlantic
text: 6/6 Frederick K. Brewington’s education came at the end of a bitter civil-rights battle that engulfed New York state, more than a decade after 'Brown v. Board of Education.' From @adamhsays: https://t.co/ohlxDahQwF

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Only if the Senate performs a genuine, thorough review of the president’s nominee for a lifetime appointment to the highest court in the land, though, is this key piece of our system of checks and balances meaningful," @NoahBookbinder writes: https://t.co/tArMqYKYpV
